question: 1 (e)
sols_html:
Using integration by parts, we get

\[\begin{aligned} \int x^2 e^{-x} dx = -x^2 e^{-x} + \int 2x e^{-x} dx\end{aligned}\]

And using integration by parts again on this integral we obtain

\[\begin{aligned} \int 2xe^{-x} dx = -2x e^{-x} + 2 \int e^{-x} dx = -2x e^{-x} -2e^{-x} +C\end{aligned}\]

we get

\[\begin{aligned} \int x^2 e^{-x} dx = (-x^2 -2x-2)e^{-x} +C\end{aligned}\]

Now that we have the antiderivative, we can compute the improper integral

\[\begin{aligned} \int_0^{\infty} x^2 e^{-x} dx = \lim_{b\to \infty}\Bigl( (-x^2-2x-2)e^{-x} \bigr|_{0}^b \Bigr) = 2\end{aligned}\]

And so the correct answer is E.
